Bio: Shima Ryū was a pioneer of early photography in Japan. The wife and collaborator of Shima Kakoku, she was the model for many of their photographs and produced her own portrait of Kakoku, which is the earliest known photograph to have been made by a Japanese woman.
Bio Preview: Shima Ryū was a pioneer of early photography in Japan.

Bio: Hanawa Yoshino was a rare woman photographer who owned and operated her own studio in Tsukiji, Tokyo's theater district, where she specialized in portraits of kabuki actors, such as Danjuro, Sadanji, and Onoe Kikugoro V.
Bio Preview: Hanawa Yoshino was a rare woman photographer who owned and operated her own studio in Tsukiji, Tokyo's theater district, where she specialized in portraits of kabuki actors, such as Danjuro, Sadanji, and Onoe Kikugoro V.

Bio: While little is known about the early woman photographer Tokuriki Sakuko, she published an essay, in which she describes taking over her husband's photography studio after his death and her experiences working with primarily female clientele.
Bio Preview: While little is known about the early woman photographer Tokuriki Sakuko, she published an essay, in which she describes taking over her husband's photography studio after his death and her experiences working with primarily female clientele.

Bio: Yamazawa Eiko was a pioneering woman who made a living as a portrait and commercial photographer in Osaka. She traveled widely, studied with Consuelo Kanaga in the U.S., and, later in her career, experimented with color and abstract art photography.
Bio Preview: Yamazawa Eiko was a pioneering woman who made a living as a portrait and commercial photographer in Osaka.

Bio: Murai Yoneko was known as a pioneer of women mountaineers. She was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s and also worked for the NHK in the 1930s and 1940s.
Bio Preview: Murai Yoneko was known as a pioneer of women mountaineers.

Bio: Born in Kumamoto, Saeki Toshiko graduated from what is now Tsuda University and taught English before becoming a housewife in Tokyo. A birding enthusiast, she published multiple books of photographs and waka poems about birds encountered in her garden.
Bio Preview: Born in Kumamoto, Saeki Toshiko graduated from what is now Tsuda University and taught English before becoming a housewife in Tokyo.

Bio: Tominaga Yoshiko was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s.
Bio Preview: Tominaga Yoshiko was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s.

Bio: Tsuchiura Nobuko trained with Frank Lloyd Wright and is known as the first woman to become a professional architect in Japan. She was also an avid photographer and member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s.
Bio Preview: Tsuchiura Nobuko trained with Frank Lloyd Wright and is known as the first woman to become a professional architect in Japan.

Bio: Mizoguchi Utako was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club and regular contributor to pictorial magazines in the 1930s.
Bio Preview: Mizoguchi Utako was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club and regular contributor to pictorial magazines in the 1930s.

Bio: Trained as a commercial photographer, Saiki Sachiko ran her own studio in Kyoto. She traveled extensively to document the lives of people living in countries along the Silk Road. Her contributions to photography were honored with an award given in her name by the Kokuten.
Bio Preview: Trained as a commercial photographer, Saiki Sachiko ran her own studio in Kyoto.

Bio: Shimada Junko was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s and regularly contributed to Fujin no tomo until the 1960s.
Bio Preview: Shimada Junko was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s and regularly contributed to Fujin no tomo until the 1960s.

Bio: Matsunaga (Satō) Tazue was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s.
Bio Preview: Matsunaga (Satō) Tazue was an active member of the Ladies Camera Club in the 1930s.

Bio: Often described as Japan's "first" female photojournalist, Sasamoto Tsuneko's career spans the turbulent Shōwa era, including the Second World War, the Occupation and Anti-Security Treaty protests, and striking coal miners.
Bio Preview: Often described as Japan's "first" female photojournalist, Sasamoto Tsuneko's career spans the turbulent Shōwa era, including the Second World War, the Occupation and Anti-Security Treaty protests, and striking coal miners.

Bio: A farmer and innkeeper, Matsuyama Tazuko was dubbed the "Camera Grandma" for her efforts to document life in her rural hometown of Tokuyama before it became Japan's largest reservoir. At her death, she left behind 600 albums and over 100,000 negatives.
Bio Preview: A farmer and innkeeper, Matsuyama Tazuko was dubbed the "Camera Grandma" for her efforts to document life in her rural hometown of Tokuyama before it became Japan's largest reservoir.

Bio: Takahashi Chiyo was a photographer who could be seen carrying Leica and Speed Graphic cameras around the country as she worked for Kyodo News. She photographed a range of subjects including sumo wrestling.
Bio Preview: Takahashi Chiyo was a photographer who could be seen carrying Leica and Speed Graphic cameras around the country as she worked for Kyodo News.

Bio: Watanabe Fujie worked on cultural promotion for the Ministry of Foregin Affairs Photo Agency and in photojournalism during World War Two, after which she resigned from the Mainichi Shimbun to work as an event and wedding photographer, employing four male assistants.
Bio Preview: Watanabe Fujie worked on cultural promotion for the Ministry of Foregin Affairs Photo Agency and in photojournalism during World War Two, after which she resigned from the Mainichi Shimbun to work as an event and wedding photographer, employing four male assistants.

Bio: A controversial photographer to this day, Kiyooka Sumiko published many nude photographs of women and young girls in both magazines and photobooks. She also wrote several books geared toward the lesbian community in Japan, focusing on poetry, literature, and general advice.
Bio Preview: A controversial photographer to this day, Kiyooka Sumiko published many nude photographs of women and young girls in both magazines and photobooks.

Bio: Okanoue Toshiko combined her training in the Japanese collage technique chigiri-e with the aesthetics and forms of postwar surrealism. Using both fashion and lifestyle magazines as the raw material for her photo-collages, her work explores relationships between technology, gender, and the postwar reconstruction.
Bio Preview: Okanoue Toshiko combined her training in the Japanese collage technique chigiri-e with the aesthetics and forms of postwar surrealism.

Bio: One of many women entering the field of photography in the postwar era, Tokiwa Toyoko critically documented the lives of women who labored with their bodies, most notably, sex workers who worked near U.S. military bases after the Allied Occupation.
Bio Preview: One of many women entering the field of photography in the postwar era, Tokiwa Toyoko critically documented the lives of women who labored with their bodies, most notably, sex workers who worked near U.S. military bases after the Allied Occupation.

Bio: Torii Kyoko began photography at the Joshi Seigakuin photo club and left school to freelance and start a photo studio where she photographed singers such as Mariko and Kubo Yukie.
Bio Preview: Torii Kyoko began photography at the Joshi Seigakuin photo club and left school to freelance and start a photo studio where she photographed singers such as Mariko and Kubo Yukie.

Bio: Imai Hisae began her career creating avant-garde art photography based on literary works. After damaging her eyesight in a car accident, she shifted her focus to become a specialist in the photography of horses.
Bio Preview: Imai Hisae began her career creating avant-garde art photography based on literary works.

Bio: Upon graduating from photography college Kumagai Kazuyo worked part time for Konishi roku and free lanced as a commercial photographer.
Bio Preview: Upon graduating from photography college Kumagai Kazuyo worked part time for Konishi roku and free lanced as a commercial photographer.

Bio: Akahori Masuko worked as a free lance photographer making images of a wide range of subjects including the Gifu women's prison, shipyards, power generating stations and more. She often contributed to photography magazines on technical aspects of photography.
Bio Preview: Akahori Masuko worked as a free lance photographer making images of a wide range of subjects including the Gifu women's prison, shipyards, power generating stations and more.

Bio: Ogawa Chieko worked as a free lance photographer in the 1950s and in the 1970s began working as a jewelry artist.
Bio Preview: Ogawa Chieko worked as a free lance photographer in the 1950s and in the 1970s began working as a jewelry artist.

Bio: Kiyomiya Yumiko is known for her postwar documentary photographs focusing on street scenes and photographs on the imperial family.
Bio Preview: Kiyomiya Yumiko is known for her postwar documentary photographs focusing on street scenes and photographs on the imperial family.

Bio: Yoshida Ruiko graduated from Keiō University and worked for NHK and Asahi News before moving to the U.S. to study photojournalism. She became well-known for her photographs of African American children documentary photographs of life during and after Apartheid in South Africa.
Bio Preview: Yoshida Ruiko graduated from Keiō University and worked for NHK and Asahi News before moving to the U.S. to study photojournalism.

Bio: A student of Ōtsuji Kiyoji and Ishimoto Yasuhiro, Ushioda Tokuko produces serial photography projects focused on everyday domestic objects, such as books and refrigerators, revealing them to be surprising and intimate portraits of their owners.
Bio Preview: A student of Ōtsuji Kiyoji and Ishimoto Yasuhiro, Ushioda Tokuko produces serial photography projects focused on everyday domestic objects, such as books and refrigerators, revealing them to be surprising and intimate portraits of their owners.

Bio: Sugiura Kunie is a multidisciplinary artist celebrated for her early experiments in color photography, painting-photographs, and photograms. A graduate of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, she has been at the center of the New York art scene since the 1960s.
Bio Preview: Sugiura Kunie is a multidisciplinary artist celebrated for her early experiments in color photography, painting-photographs, and photograms.

Bio: Watanabe Hitomi is known for documenting the student protests and counterculture in Shinjuku in the late 1960s. She was the only woman to photograph the anti-Vietnam and Zenkyōtō student protests from behind the barricades at Tokyo University.
Bio Preview: Watanabe Hitomi is known for documenting the student protests and counterculture in Shinjuku in the late 1960s.

Bio: A graduate of Nihon University, Ōishi Yoshino is an award-winning photojournalist known for her documentation of the atrocities of war, including coverage in Vietnam, Cambodia, Sudan, the Soviet Union, and more.
Bio Preview: A graduate of Nihon University, Ōishi Yoshino is an award-winning photojournalist known for her documentation of the atrocities of war, including coverage in Vietnam, Cambodia, Sudan, the Soviet Union, and more.

Bio: Born in a WWII internment camp for Japanese-Americans, Masumi Hayashi is known for her panoramic photo-collages depicting sites of trauma, such as the internment camps, abandoned prisons, and post-industrial landscapes.
Bio Preview: Born in a WWII internment camp for Japanese-Americans, Masumi Hayashi is known for her panoramic photo-collages depicting sites of trauma, such as the internment camps, abandoned prisons, and post-industrial landscapes.

Bio: One of the first Japanese women to gain widespread recognition for her photography, Ishiuchi Miyako is known for the grainy, black-and-white documentation of her hometown of Yokosuka, as well as her later color photography of textiles, including artifacts from the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Frida Kahlo's belongings.
Bio Preview: One of the first Japanese women to gain widespread recognition for her photography, Ishiuchi Miyako is known for the grainy, black-and-white documentation of her hometown of Yokosuka, as well as her later color photography of textiles, including artifacts from the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Frida Kahlo's belongings.

Bio: Furui Mizue is an award-winning photojournalist and documentary filmmaker known for her coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, especially the lives of women and children.
Bio Preview: Furui Mizue is an award-winning photojournalist and documentary filmmaker known for her coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, especially the lives of women and children.

Bio: Matsumoto Michiko is known for documenting the ūman ribu (Women's Liberation Movement) protests, summer camps, and major events and gatherings. She began traveling to New York and Paris in the mid-1970s, making portraits of promiment feminists, famous women artists, and dancers.
Bio Preview: Matsumoto Michiko is known for documenting the ūman ribu (Women's Liberation Movement) protests, summer camps, and major events and gatherings.

Bio: The daughter of authors Takeda Yasushi and Takeda Yuriko, Takeda Hana is also an essayist known for her photography of stray cats and weathered regional towns. She has worked as a freelance photographer and as a portrait photographer at the Modern Artists Library.
Bio Preview: The daughter of authors Takeda Yasushi and Takeda Yuriko, Takeda Hana is also an essayist known for her photography of stray cats and weathered regional towns.

Bio: Higashi Yumi's work focuses on the community in Ashio and the closing of the Ashio copper mine in Tochigi Prefecture. Higashi began photography as a member of the Jissen Women's College photography club in 1969 and spent the next decade returning to Ashio to photograph the effects of the mine's environmental pollution and the vibrant community connected to it.
Bio Preview: Higashi Yumi's work focuses on the community in Ashio and the closing of the Ashio copper mine in Tochigi Prefecture.

Bio: Takagi Yuriko is a photographer and designer best known for portraits taken as she traveled through Asia, Africa, South America, and the Middle East. Her work focuses on clothing forms and the human body.
Bio Preview: Takagi Yuriko is a photographer and designer best known for portraits taken as she traveled through Asia, Africa, South America, and the Middle East.

Bio: Ishikawa Mao is an Okinawan photographer and activist known for photographs that depict the dynamics between American military bases and Okinawans. She first became known for intimate documents of the relationships between American G.I.'s and the hostesses at bars in Naha. Her photographs form strong political critiques of the American bases in Okinawa and Japanese discrimination against Okinawans.
Bio Preview: Ishikawa Mao is an Okinawan photographer and activist known for photographs that depict the dynamics between American military bases and Okinawans.

Bio: Kon Michiko is known for her primarily black and white still life photographs that combine animate and inanimate elemts to intricately create surreal scenes. Often incorporating elements from the sea or objects in the process of dying, her photographs focus on the tenuous connections between life and death.
Bio Preview: Kon Michiko is known for her primarily black and white still life photographs that combine animate and inanimate elemts to intricately create surreal scenes.

Bio: Satō Nanako is a musical artist and photographer best known for her solo albums and new wave collaborations. She began to work as a professional photographer in the 1980s, working in advertising and for magazines. Satō continues to make music and photographs and her current photo work includes promotional work for other musicians.
Bio Preview: Satō Nanako is a musical artist and photographer best known for her solo albums and new wave collaborations.

Bio: Kamikura Yoshiko was introduced to photography as a college student at Keio University photographing Terayama Shūji's theater company. She moved to Los Angeles and New York to focus on becoming a photographer and studied at the International Center for Photography and Parsons School of Design. Her photographs are known for their intimate documentation of her relationships and meditations on life and death.
Bio Preview: Kamikura Yoshiko was introduced to photography as a college student at Keio University photographing Terayama Shūji's theater company.

Bio: Ushio Sayuri trained first as a hairdresser, but began shooting photography while working at a hair salon in New York City's Greenwich Village. She opened her own salon, TICK TOCK Club, in Japan in 1985, and her photography focuses on street style, fashion, and hair and makeup design.
Bio Preview: Ushio Sayuri trained first as a hairdresser, but began shooting photography while working at a hair salon in New York City's Greenwich Village.

Bio: Takada Kyōko began her photography in commercial photo design and freelance work, before publishing several travelogue photobooks documenting trips to Tunisia and Eygpt. In addition to her photography training, Takada is also a poet and essayist.
Bio Preview: Takada Kyōko began her photography in commercial photo design and freelance work, before publishing several travelogue photobooks documenting trips to Tunisia and Eygpt.

Bio: Orisaku Mineko was crowned Miss Universe Japan in 1981, and during her term she first met the photographer Ōtake Shōji. After studying in Ōtake's studio, she began freelance photography work and lived and worked in Boston, MA. Her photography focuses on landscapes and the natural world.
Bio Preview: Orisaku Mineko was crowned Miss Universe Japan in 1981, and during her term she first met the photographer Ōtake Shōji.

Bio: After studying with fashion photographer Izimi Kaoru, Ogata Hidemi traveled to New York City, where she began her career as a photographer of fashion, celebrity, athletes, and musicians. She returned to Japan in 1990, following her first solo exhibition.
Bio Preview: After studying with fashion photographer Izimi Kaoru, Ogata Hidemi traveled to New York City, where she began her career as a photographer of fashion, celebrity, athletes, and musicians.

Bio: Takahashi Junko's photography takes on a wide range of subjects, from mundane Japanese school life and portraits of receptionists, to nude bondage photography and a study of suburban development outside Beijing.
Bio Preview: Takahashi Junko's photography takes on a wide range of subjects, from mundane Japanese school life and portraits of receptionists, to nude bondage photography and a study of suburban development outside Beijing.

Bio: Onodera Yuki was born in Tokyo, but moved to Paris in the 1990s, where she has lived and worked ever since. Her photography is often extremely large-scale, and combines a variety of techniques and materials (photograms, sand, cut-outs, lace, etc.), and she otherwise distorts her images intentionally by placing foreign objects inside the camera itself.
Bio Preview: Onodera Yuki was born in Tokyo, but moved to Paris in the 1990s, where she has lived and worked ever since.

Bio: Nakamura Haruko photographed in over 30 countries during her career. In addition to her travel-based photography, which focused on both landscapes and intimate everday relationships, she also documented her own pregnancies and the younger years of her three children.
Bio Preview: Nakamura Haruko photographed in over 30 countries during her career.

Bio: Yoshiko Seino was a largely self-taught photographer who began taking photographs in her early thirties. In her relatively short career, she produced stark, quiet landscape and streetscape photography, often taken with either medium-format or 35mm cameras.
Bio Preview: Yoshiko Seino was a largely self-taught photographer who began taking photographs in her early thirties.

Bio: Ara Taeko initially trained as a waka poet and painter as well as a photographer. Her 2004 diagnosis of breast cancer has become the core subject of much of her photography since, processing the psychological and physical effects of treatment and healing.
Bio Preview: Ara Taeko initially trained as a waka poet and painter as well as a photographer.

Bio: Tobu Akiko first began taking photographs at the Columbus Hotel in the San Franscisco neighborhood of North Beach, capturing the lives of the people that lived and worked there through still lifes and intimate, candid moments.
Bio Preview: Tobu Akiko first began taking photographs at the Columbus Hotel in the San Franscisco neighborhood of North Beach, capturing the lives of the people that lived and worked there through still lifes and intimate, candid moments.

Bio: Kanamori Mayu was born in Tokyo, but studied at the American School in Japan and grew up bilingual in English and Japanese, moving to Australia in the early 1980s. Her practice often combines photojournalism, live performance/dance, and social justice issues, particularly those affecting Australian aboriginal communities.
Bio Preview: Kanamori Mayu was born in Tokyo, but studied at the American School in Japan and grew up bilingual in English and Japanese, moving to Australia in the early 1980s.

Bio: Oshida Miho is known for her black and white photographs printed by hand on baryta paper. Her work ranges from solemn scenes of former Nazi concentration camps to portraiture.
Bio Preview: Oshida Miho is known for her black and white photographs printed by hand on baryta paper.

Bio: Yoneda Tomoko is a London-based photographer whose work documents the current moment by referencing historical events, as though she is documenting the past in the present. By searching for memories that might be found in current landscapes, she unearths the complexity of Japanese history and her own relationship with society.
Bio Preview: Yoneda Tomoko is a London-based photographer whose work documents the current moment by referencing historical events, as though she is documenting the past in the present.

Bio: Yoshitake Megumi is a photojournalist whose work focuses on the culture of Syrian Bedouin tribes and Bedouin-descended people. She is a member of the Japan Professional Photographers Society (JPS), an honorary member of the Syrian Photographers Society, and a member of the Foreign Correspondents' Association of Japan (FCCJ).
Bio Preview: Yoshitake Megumi is a photojournalist whose work focuses on the culture of Syrian Bedouin tribes and Bedouin-descended people.

Bio: Tsutsumi Ako's family has owned and run the Tsutsumi Photo Studio since 1938. After studying photography in college, and traveling abroad to the United States, Tsutsumi eventually rejoined her family business in Kumamoto as director and photographer.
Bio Preview: Tsutsumi Ako's family has owned and run the Tsutsumi Photo Studio since 1938.

Bio: Nakashima Hiromi is primarily active as a magazine photographer, working freelance since 2002. In addition to her freelance magazine work, Nakashima also photographs regularly in and around Hokkaidō, focusing on animals, the natural landscape, and human labor.
Bio Preview: Nakashima Hiromi is primarily active as a magazine photographer, working freelance since 2002.

Bio: Yanagi Miwa's highly stylized photographs portray the self-image of young women imagining themselves as grandmothers and stereotypes of young women in Japan.
Bio Preview: Yanagi Miwa's highly stylized photographs portray the self-image of young women imagining themselves as grandmothers and stereotypes of young women in Japan.

Bio: Hara Mikiko is known for street photography taken without using her viewfinder and scenes captured by quietly releasing the shutter to capture chance moments.
Bio Preview: Hara Mikiko is known for street photography taken without using her viewfinder and scenes captured by quietly releasing the shutter to capture chance moments.

Bio: Nomura Sakiko's work is known for her photographs of naked men that utilize interplay between darkness and shadow. Following the death of the model who Nomura worked with since the beginning of her career she turned to landscapes, which she photographs in a style that resonates with the nudes.
Bio Preview: Nomura Sakiko's work is known for her photographs of naked men that utilize interplay between darkness and shadow.

Bio: Nakano Aiko received recognition for portraits of women and nude self portraits in the mid-1990s but since has worked prolifically in exhibiting her fashion and commerical work.
Bio Preview: Nakano Aiko received recognition for portraits of women and nude self portraits in the mid-1990s but since has worked prolifically in exhibiting her fashion and commerical work

Bio: Mogi Ayako lives and works in the artist community Nomad-mura ("Nomad Village") and her photobook documents the travels of her young family around Europe through abstract representations of moments in time.
Bio Preview: Mogi Ayako lives and works in the artist community Nomad-mura ("Nomad Village") and her photobook documents the travels of her young family around Europe through abstract representations of moments in time.

Bio: Matsumoto Noriko has received recognition for her photographs of the rabbits of Usagijima, an abandoned island taken over by feral rabbits.
Bio Preview: Matsumoto Noriko has received recognition for her photographs of the rabbits of Usagijima, an abandoned island taken over by feral rabbits.

Bio: Honda Kana's work is known for meticulously detailed collages that piece together black-and-white photographs to make surreal cityscapes and scenes including cherry blossoms and flowers.
Bio Preview: Honda Kana's work is known for meticulously detailed collages that piece together black-and-white photographs to make surreal cityscapes and scenes including cherry blossoms and flowers.

Bio: Hanayo is a Berlin- and Tokyo-based photographer, musician, and former geisha whose photographs depict her everyday life in dreamy colorscapes utilizing a high level of blur and emphasis of light.
Bio Preview: Hanayo is a Berlin- and Tokyo-based photographer, musician, and former geisha whose photographs depict her everyday life in dreamy colorscapes utilizing a high level of blur and emphasis of light.

Bio: Noguchi Rika's photographs depict scenes from nature, such as landscapes, plants, and animals, photographed in close-up or catching the light in ways that bring fresh perspectives or disorient the viewer. She also works with pinhole cameras to capture images of the sun.
Bio Preview: Noguchi Rika's photographs depict scenes from nature, such as landscapes, plants, and animals, photographed in close-up or catching the light in ways that bring fresh perspectives or disorient the viewer.

Bio: Ninagawa Mika is known for her use of vibrant colors used in self-portraits, and portraits of friends and family as well as dynamically framed images that she often manipulated with a color copier. In 2007 she pivoted to directing films and music videos.
Bio Preview: Ninagawa Mika is known for her use of vibrant colors used in self-portraits, and portraits of friends and family as well as dynamically framed images that she often manipulated with a color copier.

Bio: Kawauchi Rinko creates collections of photographs that focus on everyday details from her life that she forms into photobooks, video works, and exhibitions. Focusing her Rolleiflex or digital camera on shadows, iridescences, or the field burnings at Mt. Aso she creates relationships between light, shapes, and movement.
Bio Preview: Kawauchi Rinko creates collections of photographs that focus on everyday details from her life that she forms into photobooks, video works, and exhibitions.

Bio: Ōtsuka Chino works in photography and video to explore relationships between time and memory. Using personal and public archives she often reinserts herself into snapshots from her childhood to explore the fluidity of memories of the past. She is an Associate Professor of Photography at the University of Richmond.
Bio Preview: Ōtsuka Chino works in photography and video to explore relationships between time and memory.

Bio: Nagashima Yurie is a photographer and cultural theorist whose photographic work utilizes self portraiture and portraits of friends and family to critique the male gaze. Her written work historicizes and theorizes masculinist discourses within the Japanese photography world from the 1970s to 2000s.
Bio Preview: Nagashima Yurie is a photographer and cultural theorist whose photographic work utilizes self portraiture and portraits of friends and family to critique the male gaze.

Bio: Hiromix is best known for her use of self portraiture and playful depictions of her life which explored her everyday life as a teenager. Through her award winning work she became a cultural phenomenon, inspiring a generation of young women to pick up cameras.
Bio Preview: Hiromix is best known for her use of self portraiture and playful depictions of her life which explored her everyday life as a teenager.

Bio: Sawada Tomoko is best known for her staged self portraiture where she inhabits the roles of students, prospective arranged marriage clients, or the roles of different professions, wherein she explores the meanings and constructions of identity.
Bio Preview: Sawada Tomoko is best known for her staged self portraiture where she inhabits the roles of students, prospective arranged marriage clients, or the roles of different professions, wherein she explores the meanings and constructions of identity.

Bio: Nomura Keiko's photobooks unflinchingly examine life in Okinawa, portray women's bodies as they transform during pregnancy, and capture light as it transforms the visual world.
Bio Preview: Nomura Keiko's photobooks unflinchingly examine life in Okinawa, portray women's bodies as they transform during pregnancy, and capture light as it transforms the visual world.

Bio: Itō Mari is known for her photographic studies of the lives of the lives of ethnic minorities and the free range pigs of Yunnan Province, China.
Bio Preview: Itō Mari is known for her photographic studies of the lives of the lives of ethnic minorities and the free range pigs of Yunnan Province, China.

Bio: Best known for her portraits set against surreal backgrounds, Shiga Lieko's subjects are often depicted in striking poses along with unrelated objects. She is also well known for her work created before and after the 3.11 triple disaster when she lived in Kitakama village in Miyagi prefecture.
Bio Preview: Best known for her portraits set against surreal backgrounds, Shiga Lieko's subjects are often depicted in striking poses along with unrelated objects.

Bio: Okabe Momo's photobooks use highly saturated colors to depict relationships with the body as they follow the female to male transitions of two of her partners, and photographs the destruction and aftermath of the 3.11 triple disaster.
Bio Preview: Okabe Momo's photobooks use highly saturated colors to depict relationships with the body as they follow the female to male transitions of two of her partners, and photographs the destruction and aftermath of the 3.11 triple disaster.

Bio: Ume Kayo's street photography, portraits of her grandfather, and humorous images of school children capture startling and striking moments and produce unexpected juxtapositions.
Bio Preview: Ume Kayo's street photography, portraits of her grandfather, and humorous images of school children capture startling and striking moments and produce unexpected juxtapositions.
